newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait union in talks with KNPC on possible strike.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait union in talks with KNPC on possible strike.

text.p: A Kuwaiti oil workers' union started talks on Wednesday with the Kuwait National Petroleum Company (KNPC) on a possible strike at the oil export terminal of Mina al-Ahmadi.
The talks are headed by KNPC labour union chairman Hamad al-Souyan and chairman of KNPC Ahmad al-Mutair.
Souyan told Reuters ahead of the meeting that exports of crude and refined products were still flowing out of Ahmadi which has a 420,000 barrel per day (bpd) refinery and oil export facilities.
KNPC officials were not immediately available for comment.
About 120 workers out of 919 at Ahmadi have asked the union to help in a dispute with KNPC over its promotion system, Souyan said.
"If there was no solution there will be a strike," he said.
"It is not in the union's policy to resort to strike," he said. "(But) the nature of Kuwaiti unions is that if any union declares a strike it seeks expanding it to make it work.
"We hope to solve the problem in today's meeting...A strike does not serve the economic situation," he earlier told Reuters.
KNPC is the refining arm of the state-owned oil conglomerate Kuwait Petroleum Corp (KPC). Kuwait has an OPEC quota of two million bpd and a local refining capacity of 830,000 bpd.
In March 1995 Kuwait Oil Co (KOC) labour union launched a strike aimed at halting Kuwait's three percent share of world production to demand a reshuffle of employment grades.
